item.title: All Soulslike Games Revealed At Gamescom 2025
item.description:
Summary

  • ONL split fans, but Gamescom’s show floor and other showcases delivered many playable games.
  • A wave of Soulslikes, indie to AAA, surfaced: Black Myth: Zhong Kui, Lords of the Fallen 2, Valor Mortis .
  • Many Soulslikes aim for 2026+ release windows; wishlist them on Steam and expect some long waits.

Fan reception to Gamescom’s Opening Night Live has been mixed compared to other big press events in 2025. That said, the show floor vibes are a lot better as there are plenty of games to test out. Also, even more exciting games have been announced outside of ONL through other shows like the Future Games Show.

It’s a big week for the gaming economy globally, and even with mixed reactions, there are still plenty of games to discuss, whether fans got to play them or not. Specifically, several Soulslike games got new trailers or were announced as upcoming releases. From AAA developers to indie teams, these are the newest Soulslikes to look forward to in 2026 and beyond, all anounced at Gamescom 2025. Details may be a bit light, but these games are definitely worth Wishlisting on Steam when possible.

Black Myth: Zhong Kui

The King Of Ghosts

Black Myth: Zhong Kui
Action RPG
Action
RPG
Systems
Developer(s)
Game Science

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Powered by

Black Myth: Zhong Kui was the game chosen to close out Gamescom’s Opening Night Live event. The trailer was brief and all CG, showcasing a demon carrying a man atop a large tiger who was presumably the titular Zhong Kui. In Chinese mythology, Zhong Kui went after evil spirits, which is a decent setup for a video game. It’s being developed by Game Science, the same developer of Black Myth: Wukong .

Black Myth: Wukong was a Soulslike experience, so fans can likely expect similar gameplay from Black Myth: Zhong Kui , although they may have to wait a while to play it. Black Myth: Wukong began development before \released its first trailer in 2020, but began development before that. This could mean Black Myth: Zhong Kui is a ways off after this initial teaser, too, but anything is possible. For now, the only known platform is PC, but it could come to consoles as well.

Kaiden

Samurai Souls

  • Developer : 5th Column Studio
  • Publisher : 5th Column Studio
  • Planned Release : TBA

Kaiden is a smaller game, and was not showcased during Gamescom’s Opening Night Live. This will be 5th Column Studio’s first game, and it already looks promising. The initial trailer shows a samurai fighting against a bigger samurai, and then it ends with a creepy spider monster. Based on the trailer, fans can surmise that they will fight normal samurai and demons in this upcoming Soulslike experience.

It’s not the first samurai-based Soulslike out there, as Nioh is a major player in the scene, but the genre is more than welcoming enough to allow another game like Kaiden to make its mark. Screenshots on Steam show even more gameplay footage, including a snowy biome and stealth kills. Platforms, beyond PC, and the release date have not been divulged yet.

La Divina Commedia

Another Shot At Hell

La Divina Commedia
Action
Adventure
RPG
Systems
Developer(s)
Jyamma Games

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Powered by

La Divina Commedia was one of the many trailers shown during Gamescom’s Opening Night Live. While there was action, it didn’t quite look like gameplay. A nameless knight was facing what appeared to be some sort of puppet-like creature in the middle of the woods. There’s not much to go on, but the vibe had strong folklore undertones despite it being based on a famous epic poem.

Jyamma Games, the developer, also made Enotria: The Last Song , which was a 2024 Soulslike game about Italian folklore, so the vibe check fits. The Steam page lists Sin alignment, weapon classes, and procedurally generated dungeons, which are quite different from most Soulslikes. The Divine Comedy is an Italian epic poem from the 1300s written by Dante Alighieri, which details a man's journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven. La Divina Commedia is not the first game to be based on this epic poem, as EA put out Dante’s Inferno in 2010.

Lords Of The Fallen 2

The Second Sequel

Lords of the Fallen II
Soulslike
Action RPG
Adventure
Systems
Released
2026

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
CI Games
Powered by

Lords of the Fallen 2 is technically the third game in the series, which is confusing to keep track of. Lords of the Fallen was a 2014 Soulslike game (arguably the first non-FromSoftware Soulslike game), which was rebooted in 2023 as Lords of the Fallen, again. Now, that reboot is getting a sequel. Lords of the Fallen 2 received a CG trailer during Gamescom’s Opening Night Live with an epic narrator talking about the war against the gods.

It’s set to release sometime in 2026 for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S, although it will be an Epic Games Store exclusive on PC. It’s a bit odd to announce a game so close to launch with only a CG cutscene, but fans of the previous two games probably know what to expect. Classes, weapons, and lots of godlike bosses to slay.

Swords Of Legends

A Long-Running Series Comes To North America

Swords of Legends
Action RPG
Adventure
Systems
Developer(s)
Aurogon Shanghai

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Powered by

Swords of Legends is another upcoming Soulslike game based on Chinese mythology, like Black Myth: Zhong Kui . Also, it’s part of a giant franchise that most probably don’t know about, Gujian , as it has been exclusive to China until this point. Players probably don’t have to worry about being confused with this new game's narrative, though, as it seems easy enough to jump in. A warrior is tasked with vanquishing demons around ancient China. Simple enough.

The trailer showed a cool headless demon fighting in bamboo thickets, along with a fiery dragon. Based on descriptions from the game, players will be able to capture souls from enemies and then repurpose them for combat. This could either be like a Pokemon game or Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow , and both examples seem promising. Not much else is known about Swords of Legends , like a release window or any platforms beyond PC, but at least Gamescom’s Opening Night Live trailer showed gameplay.

Valor Mortis

Face Napoleon In A Soulslike

Valor Mortis
Soulslike
RPG
First-Person
Systems
Released
2026

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
One More Level
Powered by

Valor Mortis was part of Gamescom’s Opening Night Live pre-show, which some think had the better lineup of game trailers than the main event. It’s one of the more unique Soulslike games of the show, based on both the perspective and theme. Players play a character who used to be part of Napoleon’s army, but now they hunt fellow soldiers who are turning into demonic monstrosities around France. All of the gameplay footage was in first-person, which is not typical of a Soulslike, but it is being developed by One More Level, the makers of Ghostrunner 1 and 2, so the perspective fits with their strengths.

It kind of looked a bit like BioShock , as the main character had a glowing hand as if to suggest magical powers with dual-wielding capabilities. Since the next BioShock game has run into some trouble, along with the spiritual successor Judas , Valor Mortis may be the next best thing. It is set to arrive in 2026 for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S.

item.title: Which MGS Game Should You Choose in Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater? (I Like MGS Choice Rewards)
item.description:
Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater is a faithful remake that keeps a lot of the original game's quirks intact, and that includes the choice of your favorite MGS game when starting a new save file. Metal Gear Solid Delta gives you the options from the original Snake Eater release, but it also adds the MGS games that came out in the years after, like Peace Walker and The Phantom Pain .

In the original version of Snake Eater , your chosen MGS game determined your starting bonus equipment. That's still the case in Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater , but the items you get are different. The game also tells you what you'll get before you make your choice, so it's much easier to pick something that you know you'll use in Metal Gear Solid Delta .

Which MGS Game Should You Choose in Metal Gear Solid Delta?

When you start a new save file in Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater , you'll be asked which MGS game you like with eight options to choose from.

  1. I'm playing the MGS series for the first time!
  2. I like MGS 1 !
  3. I like MGS 2 !
  4. I like MGS 3 !
  5. I like MGS 4 !
  6. I like MGS: Peace Walker !
  7. I like MGS V !
  8. I like everything in the MGS series!

Depending on your choice, you will start the game with additional equipment in your inventory . The rewards are only uniforms and face paints, though, and they're really just for fun. Some of them have powerful additional effects, though, so you can make the game much easier if you choose the right MGS game.

All MGS Game Initial Equipment in Metal Gear Solid Delta

Here are all the additional items you'll get for choosing each MGS game in Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater .

MGS Game

Initial Equipment

I'm playing the MGS series for the first time!

Mummy Camo Pattern

I like MGS 1 !

DPM and Auscam Desert Camo Patterns

I like MGS 2 !

Desert Tiger Camo Pattern

I like MGS 3 !

Flecktarn Camo Pattern

I like MGS 4 !

Green and Brown Face Patterns

I like MGS: Peace Walker !

Banana Camo Pattern

I like MGS V !

National Flags Face Patterns

I like everything in the MGS series!

Grenade Camo Pattern

Of these, the best choice is "I like everything in the MGS series!" since it gives you the Grenade camo pattern . It's an outfit with a bunch of grenades painted onto it, but it gives you unlimited grenades while you're wearing it.

The other camo patterns you get from the MGS game choices are just cosmetic, with the exception of Mummy camo , which makes you resistant to serious injuries. To get the Mummy camo pattern, you have to choose "I'm playing the MGS series for the first time!" at the start of the game. Both the Mummy and Grenade camo patterns are incredibly helpful in Metal Gear Solid Delta , so you can't go wrong with either one.

You'll get access to the other camo patterns and face paints once you finish your first playthrough of Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater . The game isn't very long, especially compared to more recent Metal Gear Solid entries like The Phantom Pain , so even a first-time run will only take 15–20 hours from start to finish, regardless of your chosen difficulty level and control settings.

5 Images
5 Images
Follow
Followed
Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater
Shooter
Adventure
Stealth
Systems
OpenCritic Reviews
Top Critic Avg: 87 /100 Critics Rec: 93%
Released
August 28, 2025
ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood, Sexual Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Konami

Konami

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

item.title: 8 Best Survival Games Where Exploration Is Exhausting, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Survival games can offer tough gameplay experiences where exploration can be exhausting.
  • Sometimes, the tiring exploration adds to the realism, challenge, and enjoyment of a survival game.
  • Stealth and caution are essential in games like Green Hell and This War of Mine to survive the dangers encountered on the journey.

Exploring a new game world is usually fun. Immersing in the unique culture, meeting NPCs, discovering secrets, and finding a few surprises along the way can all enhance the enjoyment of the game massively. Even survival games can provide such thrills, despite their goal being to keep the protagonist, party, or community alive, which is quite a sobering task.

Still, not all games are exhilarating to navigate, causing a great deal of stress or proving to be deadly even in the most mundane circumstances, which can result in player fatigue and burnout. That said, this feeling can often add to the enjoyment of these survival games, and many of the best feature exhausting exploration.

This ranking is based on each survival game's overall quality and popularity.

8 A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead

Sneak Around & Stay Completely Silent

A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead
7.0 /10
Released
October 17, 2024

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Stormind Games
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Every sound matters in A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead , meaning that stealth and silence are a must if players have any hope of survival. A spin-off of the popular horror movie franchise, players take control of a young woman who must navigate the world with very careful sound management as she sneaks past and hides from terrifying monstrosities.

Adding to the challenge are various environmental factors, like creaky floorboards, but also the struggle the protagonist has with her chronic asthma. This means that absolute caution and concentration are required at all times, which can be mentally draining. A microphone integration system even allows for a more immersive experience in which players themselves must physically remain silent throughout the proceedings.

7 Dying Light 2 Stay Human

Either Rewarding Or Tiresome Exploration

7 Images
7 Images
Dying Light 2 Stay Human
6.9 /10
Released
February 4, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Techland
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, PlayStation 5
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Much like its predecessor, the open-world of Dying Light 2 Stay Human can be a chore to explore, especially during the night and in the early game. 22 years after the events of the first game and set in the city of Villedor, players are encouraged to scour the city for inhibitors in order to improve protagonist Aiden Caldwell's health, as well as find other survivors.

Rewards are greater during the nighttime, but the Volatiles that infest the city are much quicker, stronger, and more numerous, meaning that those who are unprepared will be easy fodder. The stamina-based parkour can be both satisfying when it goes smoothly and frustrating when players panic while hordes of rapid zombies pursue them in the darkness.

6 Miasmata

Meticulously Chart Routes & Manage Resources

3 Images
3 Images
Miasmata
Action
Adventure
Indie
Systems
Released
November 28, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
IonFx
Platform(s)
Windows
Powered by

Placing an emphasis on slow-paced exploration, Miasmata can be a struggle for many who expect a survival game with more urgency. Navigating the island can be a tedious exercise, since the landscape must be mapped out using cartography methods, tasking players with taking note of recognized landmarks in order to plot courses and remember routes.

Combining this rudimentary mapping system with the need to carefully manage resources and craft medicine to keep the protagonist's mysterious ailment at bay can be very tiresome, especially when some tasks become repetitive. Still, there is plenty to keep Robert Hughes on his toes as he hunts for the cure to his strange illness and scavenges for resources.

5 ARK: Survival Evolved

Travel Is Fraught With Potential Dangers

ARK: Survival Evolved
9.0 /10
Released
August 29, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood, Crude Humor, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
Studio Wildcard
Platform(s)
Linux, macOS, PC, PS4, Xbox One, Stadia, Switch, iOS, Android
OpenCritic Rating
Weak
Powered by

Given the large maps and diverse biomes in ARK: Survival Evolved , players can easily feel somewhat fatigued while traversing the land. Taming and riding various mounts can really help ease these feelings, especially when using flying mounts, but there are still plenty of hostile creatures roaming the landscape and other potentially unsavory players in multiplayer servers.

Survival in itself can be somewhat taxing, since nutrition, hydration, and temperature are important, making travel over long distances and far from the safety of the home base risky. Weather and the day/night cycle present challenges, too, since the patterns are randomized and unpredictable, and creatures will be more active at night when visibility happens to be lower.

4 Green Hell

Realistic Gameplay Can Cause Fatigue To Players And The Protagonist

Green Hell
8.6 /10
Released
September 5, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood, Crude Humor, Strong Language, Use of Drugs, Violence
Developer(s)
Creepy Jar
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Often praised for its realistic survival mechanics, it's certainly not easy to keep anthropologist Jake Higgins alive in Green Hell . Everything in the game is out to kill the player-character in the Amazonian jungle, from belligerent tribes and wild animals to disease and poor nutrition, so caution is advised when venturing too far from the safety of the home base.

A balanced diet is vital, as Jake will experience various issues if he does not consume enough of certain nutrients, plus good-quality sleep is important to maintain stamina. Even walking calmly can negatively impact energy levels, so it's easy for players to feel stressed and overly burdened when playing Green Hell , adding to the challenge and immersion.

3 This War Of Mine

Demoralizing When Things Go Wrong

This War of Mine
6.7 /10
Released
November 14, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood, Mild Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco, Violence
Developer(s)
11 Bit Studios
Platform(s)
Android, iOS, Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Inspired by the siege of Sarajevo, This War of Mine is a deliberately harrowing gameplay experience, designed to simulate the horrors of war and its impact on regular civilians. In the daytime, the survivors use their scarce resources to try and live another day, staying warm, finding nourishment, and aiming to boost spirits in troubling times.

During the night, one survivor may venture out to scavenge for supplies, which is always a draining experience. Encountering friendly NPCs is rare, and even in those cases, players may steal from them, which can lead to guilty feelings and depression in characters down the line. Killing hostiles has similar consequences, and the player-character can easily be wounded or murdered, too. On top of that, returning empty-handed is even more demoralizing.

2 The Long Dark

Challenging Gameplay In The Canadian Wilderness

The Long Dark
11
8.1 /10
Released
August 1, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Hinterland Studio
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Masochistic players may choose to enable permadeath if they desire more of a challenge and higher stakes in The Long Dark . Over 50 square kilometers of Canadian wilderness await as players seek to survive in the harsh conditions, with extreme cold, changeable weather, rugged terrain, and unsympathetic wildlife all presenting barriers to avoiding death.

Resting and maintaining caloric intake helps to keep energy levels high so that players can traverse the adverse landscape, and low energy levels can quickly lead to a grisly end. Whether playing through the story campaign or attempting to stay alive as long as possible in the sandbox-style survival mode, it's tiring for both players and their in-game character while adventuring in the frozen north.

1 Don't Starve

Especially Tough Early In The Game

Don't Starve
8.0 /10
Released
April 23, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Fantasy, Violence, Crude Humor
Developer(s)
Klei Entertainment
Platform(s)
Android, iOS, PlayStation 4, Nintendo Switch, PS Vita, Nintendo Wii U, Xbox One, PlayStation 3, PC
Powered by

Exploration is a risky but necessary part of gameplay in Don't Starve , and it is especially challenging for beginners and in the first few days of a new playthrough. Starting with nothing and being given no real instructions, players must venture out into the enigmatic and whimsical world to find resources that can help them survive and thrive.

Maps are randomly generated, so each new world is both vast and unfamiliar, making those first few in-game days the most difficult. There is an urgency to craft a sustainable shelter, too, so there really is no time to rest, especially since the encroaching winter makes death an even more likely outcome if the proper preparations haven't been made.

item.title: Shinobi: Art of Vengeance Gameplay - 1 Hour, No Commentary
item.description:
We got to play the reboot of the Shinobi franchise early, so here's the first hour of gameplay for your viewing pleasure.

Captured on an iBUYPOWER RDY Y70 TI B03.

item.title: How to Get All Oboro Relics in Shinobi Art of Vengeance
item.description:
There are a whopping 55 Oboro Relics to find and collect in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance , and you will not be able to get most of them on your first playthrough of a level.

Most stages will have five Relics, with some being unaccessible until you get certain traversal abilities for Joe. You'll use the Relics at the shopkeeper to unlock more items for sale; this includes Amulets, attacks, upgrades, special items, keys, and outfits.

Since some of these Oboro Relics can be tricky to locate, this handy-dandy guide will cover all of their locations in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance .

All Oboro Relics in Oboro Village in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

Oboro Relic #1

You will not be able to get this relic until you get the Sword Dive Ningi later in the Submarine Base stage. Once you have it, return to the Village Ruins checkpoint, head left, and then you'll see the chest underneath a green Yokai barrier.

Oboro Relic #2

After passing the Antechamber checkpoint, keep heading right and go on the lower-right path to find some enemies and a chest containing an Oboro Relic.

Oboro Relic #3

Once you have the Sword Dive Ningi from a later stage, teleport to the Attic checkpoint. Head to the lowest part of this area to find a green Yokai barrier. This will lead you to the Ankou Rift. Head left of the rift to find a chest with the Oboro Relic.

Oboro Relic #4

From the Collapsed Bridge checkpoint, head into the room on the right and make your way to the following area with a locked door. Slide underneath the locked door to fight some enemies and then hit the switch to open it. Continue upwards until you reach a room with a big, fiery cauldron in the middle. Walk left to find a chest on top of a platform. You should be able to double jump to reach the side of the wall and then pull yourself up to the chest.

Oboro Relic #5

Shortly after unlocking the gate that leads outside after getting the fourth Relic, you can find a chest on the main path on the ground.

All Lantern Festival Oboro Relics in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

Oboro Relic #1

After passing the boat segment , jump on top of the roof instead of walking down the path to find a hidden chest behind a tree.

Oboro Relic #2

After passing the Tower checkpoint, continue to find one of those annoying enemies that throw axes. Right above him is a secret chest with the Oboro Relic.

Oboro Relic #3

After grabbing the previous Relic, head to a path on the left to reach a combat segment with a chest as a reward.

Oboro Relic #4

After learning the Cannon Punch , break the glowing, cracked Yokai wall, and then go to the above platform to find a chest with the fourth Relic of the stage.

Oboro Relic #5

Once you reach the third paper lantern after passing the Fireworks checkpoint, go down a bit instead of going up to find an enemy guarding a treasure chest with the last Oboro Relic.

All Oboro Relics in The Mountain in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

Oboro Relic #1

You must reach the optional Mountain Peak checkpoint to find the first Oboro Relic. Start at the Waterfalls checkpoint and then make your way through the critical path until you get to the entrance of the facility. Instead of going inside, head up and follow the path to find a wall you can use your Ninja Claws on.

Oboro Relic #2

Once you climb up the path after the Waterfalls checkpoint, you'll see the chest to the left that appears inaccessible. To reach it, just go up, left, and then down to find a side entryway.

Oboro Relic #3

After getting the Ninja Claws ability, return to the Secret Factory checkpoint and head up and then left to find a chest with the Relic.

Oboro Relic #4

Once you pass the Junkyard checkpoint, there will be a segment where sharp gears will shoot at you, and you have to outrun them. When you run away from the last one, head back to the left where it came from to find a chest.

Oboro Relic #5

Fast travel to the Excavation Site checkpoint once you have access to the Ninja Claws and the Ninja Hook (Neo City). Make your way into the optional area above the Shop and you'll find the fifth relic.

All Oboro Relics in Neo City in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

Fast travel to the East District checkpoint, making your way to the right and then going up and left. You will find a green Yokai barrier that can be broken with the Sword Dive move from the Submarine Base.

Second Oboro Relic

Fast travel to the East District checkpoint once you have the Ninja Hook. Head to the right, then down, and then left to find the chest.

Third Oboro Relic

Teleport to the South District checkpoint (you will need the Sword Dive from the Submarine Base and the Ninja Hook for this one). Head into the area on the right, and you will see a green Yokai barrier that can be destroyed. You'll find a chest blocked by electricity, so you'll need to head below and to the left to find the switch to turn the power off.

Fourth Oboro Relic

From the West Entrance checkpoint, look up near the SEGA sign to see a blue point where you can use your Ninja Hook ability acquired later in the stage. You will enter an optional area on the left where you can find the Oboro Relic, an Ankou Rift, and a Shop. You will also need the Glider from the Desert level to reach the chest on the far left.

Fifth Oboro Relic

From the City Entrance checkpoint , head out to the right, past the shopkeeper, to find some platforms you can jump on to reach the final relic of the stage.

All Oboro Relics in Fish Market in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

Right when you enter the actual fish market , stand on top of the first blue truck on the path, and you'll see that the ceiling above you can be grabbed using your Ninja Claws ability.

Make your way to the right and then up to find a hidden area. Head left and then up and around to fight some enemies, and then you'll see the Oboro Relic in a chest.

Second Oboro Relic

Once you pass the Warehouse checkpoint, you will see a wall on the right before the exit that you can reach and grab using your Ninja Claws. Like the previous Relic, make your way left to find another wall to grab on to, head up, and then to the right to find some chests.

Third Oboro Relic

Stand next to the Octo Sign checkpoint , and you'll see a spinning octopus carrying platforms. Stand on one and let it carry you up. Jump up to the platform on the left, and you'll find a wall to use your Ninja Claws on. Head on the upper path, and it'll lead you to the collectible.

Fourth Relic

After passing the Storage checkpoint , you will get to a point where you need to jump onto moving shipping containers. Once you have to wall jump between two containers hung vertically, stand on the left one and let it raise you. You'll find a platform to your left; then, simply follow the path to the Relic.

Fifth Oboro Relic

Head to the Storage checkpoint area (above the Containers checkpoint). Head to the right, up, and then left to find the chest with the Relic.

All Submarine Base Oboro Relics in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

You'll need to push a yellow canister thing into a slot to activate the elevator. Before descending, look up and to the right to find a platform that'll take you to a chest.

Second Oboro Relic

After going down the elevator, pass the Floor B1 checkpoint, and then head to the left to find a switch you can hit to drop a red canister. Push it to the right so you can hop on it to reach the treasure.

Third Oboro Relic

On the left side of Floor B2, you'll need to push one of those fire canisters towards laser beams while fire shoots at you from above. You'll eventually reach a room on the critical path with a treasure chest behind some beams. Use your Ninja Claws to attach to the ceiling to find a crevice leading to a switch.

Fourth Oboro Relic

Fast travel to the Floor B3 checkpoint and then enter the path on the upper-right side of the room (you'll have to use the Ninja Claws on the wall on the left first). This will lead you to an optional area where you can find a chest containing the Oboro Relic. However, to reach it, you will need the Glider from the Desert stage first.

Fifth Oboro Relic

After draining the water underneath the Flooded Sector checkpoint, head into the room on the right to find a chest.

All Mad Train Oboro Relics in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

After passing the Aircraft Carrier checkpoint, you will see a green Yokai barrier on the main path (break it using your Sword Dive to find the first Relic).

Second Oboro Relic

After beating the robot past the Arachno Tank Carrier checkpoint , continue on the path and jump on the next cart to find a green Yokai barrier you can smash into. The chest with the Relic will be on the left side of the container.

Third Oboro Relic

Continue until you see two explosive crates blocking the entrance to one of the storage containers. Destroy the boxes and enter the container to find the third Oboro Relic.

Fourth Oboro Relic

Enter the container to the left of where you just got the third Oboro Relic to find a chest near a switch.

Fifth Oboro Relic

Once the helicopter starts chasing you, you will eventually reach some enemies, and then you'll get to a cart with a locked door. Head on top of the cart and go all the way to the end. You can enter the cart from its back entrance. Run through it to the left to find the last Oboro Relic on the stage. (This is before the Command Car checkpoint)

All Desert Oboro Relics in Shinobi Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

After going through a bit of the Dunes segment, you'll eventually reach a large chasm that leads to a shop. Head right and then down and around to find a chest containing the first Oboro Relic.

Second Oboro Relic

Head right of the Crevasse checkpoint to find a spot where you can wall jump up to a sectioned-off area. Destroy the Yokai barriers in your way, and you will eventually reach a treasure chest with the Relic.

Third Oboro Relic

Once you reach the Ruins checkpoint, head to the left and then follow the path down to eventually reach the Astral City checkpoint. From there, you will see a glowing purple barrier that needs to be shut off by reaching the top of this section and hitting a switch. Once you make it to the switch, drop down to the area right underneath you to find a chest.

Fourth Oboro Relic

Fast travel to the Astral Ruins checkpoint and then head into the optional purple area on the left. You'll need to use your Glider and smooth sailing skills to make it to the chest with the Relic.

Fifth Oboro Relic

After passing the Astral Ruins checkpoint towards the end of the stage, you'll find the chest containing the Oboro Relic on the critical path, just off on a ledge to the left after a wall jump section.

All ENE Corp Laboratory Oboro Relics in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

Once you pass the West Control Center checkpoint, you'll need to go to the room above it to break a machine. Before leaving, look to the top left to find a hidden chest with an Oboro Relic.

Second Oboro Relic

After you shut off the power in the West Control Center , head down and stay on the lower path to find one of the Elite Squads. Keep heading right to a tight corridor; once it splits into two, head right instead of up to find another Relic.

Third Oboro Relic

After you unlock all the doors in the facility, return to the Control Center checkpoint. There are two moving platforms here (one to the left and one to the right). Take the one on the right, and it'll lead you to a challenge room where you need to use your glider over some updrafts while avoiding lasers.

Fourth Oboro Relic

From the East Control Center checkpoint, head left and then down the moving platform. Now, run all the way to the left to find a chest with an Oboro Relic.

Fifth Oboro Relic

After passing the shopkeeper by the entrance, you will see a locked door and a chest behind it. Just jump on the nearby moving platform, head to the right, drop down, and then head left to find the chest near a tough enemy.

All Kaiju Oboro Relics in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

Go left past the Airway Entrance checkpoint , take the draft up with your glider, and then enter the room to the right to find a platforming challenge with a Relic as the reward.

Second Oboro Relic

From the Throat checkpoint, make a far jump and a dash to the right to find a grappling hook leading you to an area above. You'll find the chest on the path in the upper left area.

Third Oboro Relic

After passing the Lungs checkpoint, you will reach a second wind draft section, taking you up. Look to the left to find a hidden little area containing a chest.

Fourth Oboro Relic

Once you reach the Stomachs checkpoint, head to the path on the left to reach an optional area with a chest.

Fifth Oboro Relic

You can find this Relic in a chest to the left of the Second Stomach checkpoint . It's near one of the Elite Squad fights.

All Assault Oboro Relics in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance

First Oboro Relic

You'll get to a section on the critical path before the Bunker checkpoint where a door will lock automatically, and enemies will jump you. Defeat them, and the first Oboro Relic will be yours for the taking.

Second Oboro Relic

After passing the Bunker checkpoint, you'll see some green Yokai barriers on some storage containers. In the second one, you'll find the Relic.

Third Oboro Relic

A little bit after passing the Siege Tower checkpoint, you'll find a green Yokai barrier you can use your Sword Dive on to find a secret area with a very tough platforming challenge that will reward you with the Oboro Relic and an Elite Squad fight.

Fourth Oboro Relic

After passing the Ruse's Castle checkpoint, you'll eventually reach some spinning fire obstacles. You'll see a tiny spot you can roll into on the left before using your Ninja Claws on a wall. (It's right underneath the Throne Room checkpoint).

Fifth Oboro Relic

Take the path to the right of the Throne Room checkpoint to drop into a different area --look to the left to find a chest with the relic.

Here's a list of every item that will become available in the Shop in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance (and how many Relics you will need to make them show up!)

  • For One Relic

    • Knee Attack - 1500 Gold

  • Two More Relics

    • Kunai Burst - 1500 Gold

    • Aquatic Warrior Amulet - 3500 Gold

  • Four More Relics

  • Six More Relics

    • Launch Kick - 3500 Gold

  • Six More Relics

    • Sakura Slayer outfit - 8000 gold

  • Ten More Relics

  • 20 More Relics

    • Jungle Creeper Outfit - 12000
